nodes.title: II.1. Stelae and accompanying structures: Funerary and non-funerary structures
Trama Nakgu DoringGra ma nag gu rdo ring
Basic site data
nodes.body:
• Site name: Trama Nakgu DoringGra ma nag gu rdo ring
  • English equivalent: Black Gra ma Long-stones
  • Site number: C-88
  • Site typology: II.1b
  • Geographic coordinate (N. lat.): 30º 11.4΄
  • Geographic coordinate (E. long.): 83º 15.3΄
  • Elevation: 4650 m
  • Administrative location (township): HorpaHor pa
  • Administrative location (county): Drongpa’Brong pa
  • Survey expedition: UTAE
  • Survey date: April 17, 2001
  • Contemporary usage: None.
  • Identifiable Buddhist constructions: None.

nodes.title: General site characteristics
nodes.body: The highly degraded Trama Nakgu DoringGra ma nag gu rdo ring is located on the northern edge of the broad Yarlung TsangpoYar lung gtsang povalley, near where the NeutsangpoNe’u gtsang po (a major tributary) debouches into it. The terrain is very sandy and studded with dramagra ma brush and grasses. The site has open views only in the south and east. The sandy ridge on which Trama Nakgu DoringGra ma nag gu rdo ring was built, cuts off the northern and western vistas. There are nine much eroded standing stones at the site, seven or eight of which are broken. Two or three types of beige and gray metamorphic rocks were employed in construction of the monument.

nodes.title: Oral tradition
nodes.body: Like other sites of this typology in the general region (upper Yarlung TsangpoYar lung gtsang po drainage basin), Trama Nakgu DoringGra ma nag gu rdo ring is ascribed to the ancient MönMon or elemental deities.

nodes.title: Enclosure
nodes.body: The general configuration of the enclosure is discernable through the few remaining in situ stones of the walls. The most visible wall section is in the north, next to the pillars. Much of this wall, however, has been dislodged or engulfed by shifting sands and vegetation.

nodes.title: Pillars
nodes.body: Seven of the nine uncut stelae form a north-south oriented row 4 m in length. The other two stelae run in a perpendicular fashion near the fragmentary north wall of the enclosure. The tallest pillar is tabular (1 m [height] x 1 m [basal girth] x 20 cm [thickness]). The thin edges of this pillar face in the southeast and northwest directions. The second tallest pillar measures 60 cm x 90 cm. The remaining specimens are significantly smaller. There is also an uprooted pillar 1.7 m in length at the site.
